text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,
and today we're interviewing Tessa Court,
the Founder and CEO from IntelligenceBank.
Tessa, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about IntelligenceBank?
- Yeah, sure.
So thanks for having me.
Super excited to talk a little bit

about IntelligenceBank
and what we're doing.
So we are a content governance platform,
and our, I guess our premier product
is marketing operations.

And basically what we
do is we help clients

and marketing clients not
get fired and not get sued

based on the creative
that walks out the door.
So really our reason for being

is to put a process
around content governance

and how people create
content, get it approved,
and then also distribute it seamlessly

to their customers or
partners or whoever it is

and just putting a process
around that content.

- Wow, I mean, Tessa,
you were recently rated

the best marketing resource
management software
for advanced search and media.

So what I wanna know is what
is it that sets you guys apart
from most of your other competitors?
- Yeah, I mean, look,

I think there's things
that we really focus on.
So, we're a relatively smaller company
in a very large market,
and we have operations here in Australia,
but also in the U.S. and Canada as well.
And we've got lots of clients in Europe.

And so for us, it's about
focusing on the product.
So, I have an analogy.

When you think about the
coffee shops that have,
they're a little hole in the wall,
but they have a line around the corner,
it's just because the product's great.

And so we are very much a
product-first organization.
So that's really important for us.

Also, I think, I guess tapping
into what I said before,
geo-expansion

and being able to service
clients wherever they are.

We have lots of clients who've
got multinational users.
We've got users in 55 countries.
So I guess also for us,

being global first and
having that approach,

and obviously AWS with
its footprint everywhere
is able to help us do that as well.
And I guess the last thing for us,

and what's made us pretty
successful from that perspective,

is building our partner network
and relationships as well.
- Well, I definitely agree with you,

and I love your analogy
with the coffee shop,
'cause it's so true.

You always get that coffee
shop that has a huge line,

and it's just 'cause
the coffee tastes great.
So, testament to your product.

And Tessa, last year
for you guys was huge.

You had the investor, Five
Elms, supporting your growth
both here in Australia and the U.S.,
and you had some huge things going on.
So what I wanna know is what's next
for IntelligenceBank in 2022?
- Yeah, so for us, it's really continuing

on that product journey,
first and foremost.
So again, we do believe
if we have the best product in the world,
everything else stems from that.
So, really doubling down on that.
So I think we've doubled our dev team
in the last six months.

So we received investment
in June 30th, 2021.

So we're only about seven and
a half months in right now.
So that's really our focus,
and we have done a lot of hiring.

So, obviously having that
level of investor join,
I guess, us as a partner,
what's great about that is that
we're able to then execute
and hire the team to deliver on this.
So in addition to doubling our dev team,

we really doubled everyone
else as well at the same time.
So, and I guess this year it's about,

I guess this calendar
year it's about execution.

So we put a lot of the
building blocks in place,

and it's about just having a
strategy and sticking to it.

- Well, I love that you guys
are so focused on the product.
It's really amazing.
And Tessa, what do you think will be
some of the biggest challenges and threats

facing your industry I guess
in the next couple of months,
six to 12 months?
- Yeah, I mean, I think with any industry,

especially in software,
there's a lot of noise
at the lower end.
And sometimes I say to clients,
"If you squint your eyes

"sometimes all the products
look the same out there."
So for us, I think differentiation

is a really really important
part of what we do,
and I guess for our company,

we are really focused
on regulated industries.
So we service everyone.

So we've got clients in
cosmetics and fashion
and lots of places,

but our sweet spot, like
we're very clear about that,

in the sense that we work
closely with financial services,
government, education, and healthcare,

because that's where there's
a lot of talent involved,
or if you make claims on advertising

or communications that
you can't substantiate

that you've gone through
an approval process,
that's really where the problem lies.
So, again, we do have a sweet spot,
and that's really helped us be,

I guess, a shining light
through a lot of the noise.
So I think for clients where they say,
oh, you can handle
a new regulation that's come out of
some sort of Royal Commission,

that we can handle that,
that they know that,

but it's also serves as
a guiding light for us

as kind of more noise
comes into the market.
- Yeah, absolutely.
There's so much opportunity right now,

which is really exciting
for your business,

and IntelligenceBank has a
great foothold in governments,
as you mentioned.
You briefly touched on it,
but what other sectors are critical

to the next phase of your
growth at IntelligenceBank?
- Yeah, so as I mentioned before,

we are focused on clients
in regulated industries.
So, again, in going back to that concept,
if you can get fired, fined, and sued
for the creative that walks out the door,
I mean those are our ideal clients.
The good news is with more regulations,
there's more of those.

And what we're seeing
in the market right now
is that there's really this blending of
compliance and also MarTech.

So it's like if MarTech and
RegTech had a love child,
you'd get IntelligenceBank,

and that's kinda how we
like to think about it.
So, I guess for government, I mean,

those sorts of clients have
to be very, very specific

on talent usage and how
they're even portraying,
even if it's a construction project
sponsored by the government,

do you have a hard hat on
in an ad, as an example?
Or a piece of communication?

'Cause if you don't, you're
in all sorts of strife,
as as an example.
And then the security comes into that.
So, a lot of our clients as well,

especially in government,
really appreciate,
I guess, some of the hosting flexibility
that we're able to provide.
So, as an example, we have clients where,
a cloud, a traditional cloud service

would not be viable just given
the sensitivity of the data.
But in partnership with AWS,

we're able to offer a
concept called Private Cloud

where we're still hosting
and managing the software
from IntelligenceBank's side,
but it's in their account,

or it's a segmented
account away from others.
So that just gives government departments

with very sensitive data
peace of mind as well,
which is great.
- Tessa, thank you so much.

I always love it when I
have a female on the show.
You're such an inspiration,
and it's a really great partnership
between AWS and IntelligenceBank.

So I will be following
your journey very closely.
If anyone has any questions,

please pop them in the
comment section below,
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much, Tessa.
- Thanks.
